He then traveled to various prefectures, climbed famous mountains, and received full ordination at Yuquan Temple in Jingzhou.
He heard that Vinaya Master Huawei of Anguo Temple and Vinaya Master Yibian of Baoen Temple in Chang'an were models in the Dharma gate, and went to study under them.
He resolved all doubts and understood all meanings, and was regarded as the foremost disciple of the two masters.

In the 14th year of Tianbao, Emperor Xuanzong said, People from the north inherit the temperament of the region and often have erroneous customs. Even in Buddhist temples, they still engage in riding and archery. If there is no teaching to stop them, how can they be restrained?
He ordered Cai to give admonitions and preside over the ordination platform.
In the first year of Zhide, Emperor Suzong ascended the throne.

Prime Minister Du Hongjian petitioned for Cai to reside at Longhui Temple, and the emperor decreed that he be made a great virtuous teacher in charge of teaching in the region north of the Yellow River.
He was ordered to instruct and reform the customs of the barbarians and follow the path of the Vinaya.
He was again ordered to establish a Lotus Sutra Dharma Assembly for the country.
After the imperial carriage returned, he repeatedly received imperial letters, and in the end, he especially focused his mind on the Mahayana sudden teachings.
In the second year of the Yongtai era, the traitorous minister Pugu Huaien externally recruited and induced barbarian tribes, and internally hoarded gold and weapons.
Cailun earnestly advised him to wear fur robes and not to slaughter the Chinese people.
In the third year of the Dali era, he was summoned to serve as the great virtuous one of Zhangxin Temple.
At that time, the governor of the prefecture, the Duke of Guozhong Chang, had long admired Cailun's reputation and discussed the Way with Ren Gong, the protector of the frontier, at the right time.
In the winter of the thirteenth year, he manifested illness in his body. On the eighth day of the last winter month, he calmly sat on a rope bed and peacefully passed away, at the age of fifty-six.
In the second month of the following year, his spirit was moved to the northwest corner of the temple.
Previously, there was a villager named Shi Yong who was serving in the city. On that night, before the watch, he heard the sound of flutes and zithers coming from the west, which were heavenly music.
A strange fragrance scattered from the sky, a sign of rebirth in a pure land.

Since Cai returned from Chang'an to the borderlands, after receiving the favor of the Duke of Guo, he greatly promoted meritorious deeds and established this pure abode, all due to Cai's earnest encouragement.
The emperor posthumously bestowed the title of Able Awakened One on the Great Master, along with a set of purple robes, the honor ofè¿½é  reaching the borderlands.
In the Tianfu period, Tingwei Piao Wang Dan wrote a stele inscription praising his virtues.
Biography of Shi Daocheng of Zhangxin Temple in the Capital of the Tang Dynasty. Shi Daocheng, whose surname was Liang, was a person from Jingzhao.
His father was a secretary in the Secretariat.
Born with extraordinary features, he detested meat and fish. Leaving home was like returning, without any hesitation.
Suddenly encountering a Chan monk, who rubbed his head and named him Daocheng.
The water bottle and staff always followed him, mysteriously conforming to the Vinaya precepts. He was called a Vinaya novice monk.
After receiving full ordination, he studied and listened to the Nanshan Vinaya, and had a thorough understanding of the precepts.

However, his nature was straightforward and simple, and he did not stay in one temple for long. He stayed at temples such as Fengen, Zhuangyan, and Caotang, wherever he happened to be. He was very concerned about protecting life.
In the second year of Jianzhong, he was sitting in meditation on Mount Yunyang, when a tiger roared and entered the gate.
Cheng calmly spoke to it, and the tiger wagged its tail, lowered its ears, and left.
He moved to live in Zhangxin Temple. Someone asked him the reason, and Cheng said:
How can one who has left the household life be confined to one place?
In the Western Regions, the monks divide the rooms into three periods, so that they do not become attached, and it is easy to establish the 'gate of contemplation'.
Otherwise, how can one be broad-minded and tolerant?

On the eighth day of the second month in the second year of Zhenyuan, the emperor received the bodhisattva precepts at the temple. The capital city looked up to him, and the gifts were abundant. He received them and then gave them to the two fields.
In the fifth year, the Emperor visited the temple and asked Cheng about the Dharma gate of cultivating the mind.
He also ordered the Empress, the Prince, and the concubines to receive the bodhisattva precepts from him.
In the fourth month of the sixteenth year, he was granted the title Great Perfection.
On the eighteenth day of the ninth month of the nineteenth year, he passed away at this temple.

The Biography of Qingche of Longxing Temple in Zhongling of the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Qingche of Longxing Temple in Zhongling of the Tang Dynasty, Shi Qingche, whose place of origin is unknown.
He traveled around the Vinaya school, secretly guarding the sense doors, taking impermanence as his teacher, and only doing good deeds.

At first, under Vinaya Master Daoheng of the Northern Courtyard of Kaiyuan Temple in Wu Garden, he personally comprehended the profound principles, and his fame spread far and wide, with everyone praising him.

In the eighth year of the Yuanhe era of Emperor Xianzong's reign, in the year Gui Si, he compiled the commentary in twenty fascicles, also collecting the essential teachings of various masters, explaining the commentary of Nanshan, and calling it the Collection of Meanings, or Hou Tang.
It was completed in the tenth year.
Now, many lecturers in Yuzhang, Wuchang, and Jinling often follow this interpretation.
I have always read this record, which is extensive and the basis of the school.
I do not yet know its end.
The author says:
Is not Venerable Che's words and actions too concise?
The author replies:
There is a basis for being extensive or concise, which is called the true record.
In the past, could the Grand Historian not have wanted to elaborate on the events of the Three Dynasties?
It is only that before the Tang and Yu, the historians were simple and concise, how could later generations record it?
Now it is not as rich and abundant, this is the reason.
Moreover, it is the same as not recording those who did not come to respond to the summons.
Wherever there is unevenness in being extensive or concise, one must remove the ridicule and yield.

The Biography of Shi Shang Heng of Jingyun Temple in Fuzhou during the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Shi Shang Heng of Jingyun Temple in Fuzhou during the Tang Dynasty, Shi Shang Heng, whose surname was Rao, was from Nancheng in Linchuan.

From childhood, he had knowledge and, in the years of aspiring to study, he made up his mind to leave the household life. He followed his maternal relatives, sought acceptance in the monastic order, and was taught to recite Buddhist scriptures, memorizing a thousand words a day.
In his prime, he received the precepts from Great Master Dayuan of Nanyue and studied diligently.
During the Dali era, without leaving his parents' homeland, he requested to be affiliated with Jingyun Temple.
His practice was without fault, and many years passed.
He was especially devoted to lecturing on the Collection of Activities of Nanshan.

In the beginning of the Zhenyuan era, he moved to Longxing Temple in Yuzhang, where he associated with Fazhen of Mount Lu, Lingyou of Tiantai, Fayezhi of Jingmen, Shencuo of Xingguo, and Huijin of Jianchang. Their harmonious cooperation was like the combination of a flute and a panpipe, and their mutual support was like water and milk.
He taught the Dharma to kings and ministers, and thus befriended the four gentlemen: Minister Jiang, Duke Gongfu, Yan Zhenqing, Duke Lu, Yang Ping, and Wei Dan.
He upheld the precepts and lectured on the Four Part Vinaya, causing countless people to reform their conduct and repent their sins.
For more than twenty years, he sat on the sweet dew platform, held eighteen assemblies to rescue sentient beings, and saved more than 15,000 men and women in the east of Yanzhou.
In the tenth year of Yuanhe, he suddenly fell ill and passed away on the jiaxu day of the tenth month at Donglin Temple on Mount Lu. His whole body was returned to a stone tomb on South Hill.
He lived for seventy-seven years and entered nirvana for fifty-five summers.
His disciples planted pine and cypress trees. Bai Juyi of Taiyuan wrote an inscription for a stone pagoda.
Biography of Shi Huilin of Yongfu Temple in Qiantang during the Tang Dynasty. Shi Huilin, whose name was Baoyu, had the surname of Ke and was from Xin'an.
At a young age, he studied under Jin Heshang at Xifeng of Lingyin and was taught the essentials of the Dharma without any need for repeated questions.
In the beginning of the Dali era, he received full ordination at the Lingjiu Mountain Assembly and studied the Three Teachings, comprehending them all.
He did not enjoy fame and fortune, but preferred springs and rocks. He entered Tianyan for more than twenty years.
Tianyan is the same as Tianmu. The mountain is 3,000 feet high and 300 li in circumference, comparable to Tianzhu and Lu Fu.
There are two lakes on top, called the left and right eyes. It is difficult to climb and takes several days to reach the peak.
There are many dragons, with three ponds.
The uppermost pond cannot be approached by people, and the foul smell is unbearable to look at for a long time.
Some say that the mountain god takes the form of a white deer and meets with the dragon of Zhenze every fifth month, and there will surely be violent storms.
Lin lived here, often experiencing strange things, but his mind was unmoved.
In the Dinghai year of the Yuanhe era, the prefect, Libu Yuanwai Chengnan Tuzhi, invited him to ascend the platform at Yongfu Temple.
In the spring of the Ji Chou year, Prefect Pei Changdi, the Minister of the Army, invited him to the altar in Tianzhu Temple.
After completing the ordination of people, he returned to the temple to lecture and instruct students for nearly twenty years.

The Prefect Zu Si Lang Zhong Lu Ze, the Minister of the Court of Judicial Review Yang Ping, the Court Gentleman for Evaluations Lu Yuan Fu, the Court Gentleman for Ceremonials Bai Juyi, the Chamberlain for Ceremonials Li You Gong, the Minister of the Court of Judicial Review Cui Shan, and the Minister of the Court of Judicial Review Lu Yi Xiang, the Lords of the Nine Regions in succession, all retired from office and visited the temple, paying homage and inquiring about the fundamental meaning of Buddhism, and understanding the nature and characteristics of phenomena.
These famous officials and scholars, with their lofty literary skills, were either called the Confucius of Abhidharma or the Bodhisattva of Supreme Power. How could Lin not have moved them?
On the twenty-fifth day of the fourth month in the sixth year of the Taihe era, he passed away at the age of eighty-three, with sixty-four years as a monk.

On the twelfth day of the fifth month of that year, he was buried on the western mountain behind Yong'an Temple, to the left of Marble Hill. The stone pagoda still stands majestically.ğŸ”½Biography of Shenmiao of Xingguo Temple in Jiangzhou during the Tang Dynasty.
Shi Shenmiao, whose surname was Cheng, was from Lantai in Jingzhao.

He was born extraordinary and outstanding. At the age of seven, he left home to pursue the dust. He admired the precepts from afar and received full ordination from Master Xicao on Nanyue. He then visited Chan Master Dajidian in Zhongling.
However, his mind was on the Surangama Sutra, and his practice was in the Four Part Vinaya. He also had a thorough understanding of other teachings.

In the eighth year of Dali, the court issued an edict to test those who had left home by suspending the sutras, treatises, and vinaya in three categories. Only those who passed the middle level were allowed to be ordained.
Miao participated in the selection and was ordered to be assigned to Xingguo Monastery in Jiujiang.
Later, he moved to Donglin Temple, which was the old site of Yanmen Jiewen, where there was the Ganlu Ordination Platform and Bailian Pond.
After residing there, he continued to promote Buddhist activities. Although he studied sutras and treatises to nourish his mind, he ultimately focused on the Vinaya.
He was emaciated and looked haggard. The governor and his disciples treated him with medicine, but he did not wish to take it.
In the ninth month of the twelfth year of Yuanhe, he fell ill and passed away sitting upright in the temple on the twenty-sixth day.

On the nineteenth day of the tenth month, his disciples buried his whole body to the west of the temple, north of the road, next to the tomb in Yanmen - like Sengquan's burial near the tomb of Guo Wen.
He was 74 years old and had been a monk for 51 years.

He used the fat of diligent mind and the wheel of non-retrogression, and beat the drum of fearlessness with the power of bravery and strength. Therefore, he ascended the platform and upheld the Dharma for thirty years. He ate from one bowl and lived in one room. He sewed hemp cloth to make clothes and used straw to make a cushion to sit on.
As a result, the offerings of the laypeople gathered before him, and he immediately returned them to the inexhaustible treasury of the monastery to be shared with the assembly.

Every night, he held an incense burner and a candle, practiced circumambulation, and made offerings to the Buddha, following the twelve periods of the day, with few omissions. He did this for forty-five years.
In his life, he often met Bai Letian, who was the magistrate of the prefecture, and they became good friends.
When [Xuanlang] passed away, [Bai Letian] grieved and composed a stele inscription, which said:

We originally formed a society for the incense and fire of bodhi, together despising the body of afflictions and bubbles in the lightning. There is no need to be sorrowful and follow the master, first inviting the Western [Pure Land] to be the host.
Biography of Huiling of Shengshou Temple in Jingzhao, Tang Dynasty Biography of Huiling of Shengshou Temple in Jingzhao, Tang Dynasty Shi Huiling, whose place of origin is unknown.

From a young age, he had the potential to leave the dust, diligently reciting and practicing, and when he reached the age to receive the precepts, his conduct was perfect. He focused his mind on the Vinaya, exploring the pros and cons of upholding the precepts, and his practice matched his understanding, with his mind and mouth in harmony.
Therefore, his lectures and teachings became widely known.
People all revered him with awe, regarding him as a spiritual being.

In the seventh year of the Dazhong era, Emperor Xuanzong visited Zhuangyan Temple, paid homage to the Buddha's tooth relic, ascended the great pagoda, and inquired of the elders. He then bestowed purple robes on them.
In the sixth month of that year, an edict appointed Huiling as the abbot of the new temple.
The emperor looked to the northwest of the temple, where Zhizhi Temple had been abolished, and issued an edict saying:

I have been leisurely governing and enjoying the scenery, fortunately at the majestic temple. Its halls are layered and corridors connected, with connected eaves and towering roofs. The secluded rooms and secret chambers are winding and open, with dense bamboo and verdant pine trees casting shade and towering. Walking, one loses the way. Among the Buddhist palaces of the world, this one is lofty and unparalleled.
When it was first built, as the area west of the capital city, Kunming Lake, was low-lying, a wooden pagoda 300 feet high was built.
When I was still a prince, I would come to this monastery and see these magnificent things.

As for Zongchi Temple, it was built during the Daye period. Its layout and regulations are exactly the same as Zhuangyan Temple. Now the statues have been destroyed, and the temple has become overgrown with weeds. The fragrant paths are overgrown, but the foundations still remain.
This temple should be allowed to be rebuilt, to fulfill my wishes.

On the eleventh day of the third month, he ordered Bianzhang, the head seat of the three teachings, to take charge of repairing the temple, and when the work was completed, he promoted Ling as the leader, and bestowed purple robes on Yechuan of Chongsheng Temple and Xuanchang of Foshou Temple, who were made the abbot and the chief monk respectively.
The positions in Lingjiu Temple were all arranged by the pure assembly, and the emperor respected them.
The temple always offered pear blossom honey, which was white in color and tasted better than ordinary wax.
The new Lingjiu Temple is completed.
If we investigate that Ling Gong was once involved in the translation and proofreading of the Yongtai period of Emperor Dezong, then he would have been over a hundred years old!
If we do not see Amoghavajra, then there is no way to know his age in the summer of that year.

The Biography of Changda of Poshanshan Temple in Wuzhou of the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Changda of Poshanshan Temple in Wuzhou of the Tang Dynasty, Shi Changda, whose name was Wenju, was a native of Haiyu with the secular surname Gu.
He left his hometown and went to Dayun Mountain in Heyang, traveling to study in various famous temples in the Jiang and Huai regions.
He mastered the harmony of the middle way, perfected the precepts, and specialized in lecturing on the Vinaya Commentary of Nanshan.

Later, he sought the perfect sound of the Nirvana Sutra and the calming and contemplation of the Lotus Sutra, and also studied the Yin Fu Jing, the Laozi, the Zhuangzi, and the works of the hundred schools. As for other studies done in spare time, he mastered the calligraphy of the two Wangs.
Later, he traveled to various places to study Chan, and reached the ultimate in the Chan school.
Suddenly, Emperor Wuzong destroyed Buddhism, and he sighed:
My life is not in accord with the times. It is not for me after this!
Therefore, he remained silent, living in the mountains, and even though he abandoned his fur coat and fled the world, he was not depressed.
When Emperor Xuanzong rebuilt the Dharma banner and reestablished the monasteries,
the people of the entire region were all guided by his teachings, so Prefect Wei Shu especially respected him greatly.

His body did not wear silk, and his room was only covered with vines. The four assemblies knew to take refuge, and the various directions admired his transformation, as pure as a white crane or egret.
In the twelfth year of the Xiantong era, the monks and laypeople of the entire city invited him to succeed as the teacher of the four assemblies.
Sometimes wandering in the fields, sometimes whistling and frolicking by the sea, he did not leave the forests and valleys, often spending several years there.
Even if noble officials came to his door in single carriages, they could not see him.
He composed the Song of Practicing the Way in the Green Mountains in the style of the Yuanhe era, using seven-character quatrains, and spread it among the people's lips and tongues.

Suddenly, on the morning after the self-admittance ceremony, he gathered the assembly in the long corridor, joined his palms together, and finally took a long farewell. His words were very sincere and upright.

He then lay down sick and did not get up. He fasted for seven days and passed away. It was the sixteenth day of the ninth month in the fifteenth year of the Xiantong era. He was seventy-four years old, and had been a monk for fifty-one years.
His disciples Huiqing and Chuanlang respectfully placed his coffin three hundred steps southeast of the temple.

The following year, a stupa was built, and Chen Yan of Yingchuan wrote the stele inscription. Zhou Si of Runan, the magistrate, collected donations from the faithful, and a stele was erected in the fourth year of the Ganyuan era.ğŸ”½Tang Dynasty Biographies of Eminent Monks, Scroll 10, Biography of Danfu of Kaiyuan Temple in Yuezhou, Tang Dynasty.
Shi Danfu, whose place of origin is unknown.
He was very perceptive and always spoke straightforwardly. He was diligent in teaching and upheld the proper standards.
In the customs and geography of Kuaiji, the Vinaya is a vast repository.
Those who followed Danfu's guidance were like iron filings drawn to a magnet.
He originally studied under Vinaya Master Wen of the Guangwen Temple. Wen was a disciple of Xinggong, and Danfu was Xinggong's great-grandson.
He followed the correct teachings and thoroughly understood the profound principles.
After Tan Yi and Xuanyan Yan of Yue, few could keep up with him. Danfu's fame and influence surpassed that of the previous masters.
However, at that time, the skilled craftsmen of Yunwen were in vogue, and they were just in the middle of the great precepts. When practicing the rituals, they followed the wind and bowed down.
At the end of the Xian Tong era, he went out to transmit lectures to people such as Zhi Zhang. His Dharma heirs still exist today.
I have heard that he wrote a manual, but I have not yet obtained it. Alas!
What a pity!

The Biography of Dharma Xiang of Lingguang Temple in Jiahe, Wuzhou, Tang Dynasty. The Biography of Dharma Xiang of Lingguang Temple in Jiahe, Wuzhou, Tang Dynasty. Shi Dharma Xiang, whose surname was Yu, was from Changshui in Wu.
He was born in the Tianbao period. As a child, he was extraordinary. At the age of seven, he became a monk and recited the entire Lotus Sutra in three weeks.
At the age of twenty, he went to Anguo Temple in Chang'an and received full ordination, which was during the Dali period.
He then studied the Vinaya teachings in the capital, and was well-versed in the similarities and differences between the various texts, and after eleven years, he became a master of the subject.
After returning to the East to transmit the Dharma, students gathered like a forest.
The Prefect of Wu prefecture reported to establish a precepts platform at Kaigen Temple, and he was selected to preside over the platform.
He was soon appointed as a teacher and was unanimously chosen as the head of the temple, always giving the two assemblies the precepts.
He carried a water strainer and did not keep extra utensils.
Birds would perch beside his seat, and he would not chase them away.
On the tenth day of the second month in the first year of the Huichang era, at noon, three chimes, he told his disciples Qing Jun and Qing Gao:
I am about to pass away.
He then passed away in the full-lotus position on his right side.
At that time, the assembly heard clear and bright flute music during the day, which was heavenly music;
in the evening, they saw a strange light.
He was eighty-nine years old, and had been a monk for sixty-nine years.
In the fourth month, his stupa was moved to the fields of Laisu village, which is the White Stupa.

Later, his disciples, led by Cao Xin, the Prefect of Yizhou, and Wu Fang, the Director of the Imperial Chancery, repaired the stupa and opened it, seeing that the remaining bones were copper-colored, and the tongue was intact, like a lotus flower, and the teeth were all forty-two.
They bathed it with fragrant water and reburied it, which was on the twenty-second day of the fifth month in the second year of Jingfu, the year of Gui Chou.

Gao's disciple was Gong Jing, Jing's disciple was Xing Yun, Yun's disciple was Ren Biao, Biao's disciple was Xuan Gao, and Gao was originally a pure and honest monk. He, together with Hong Qi, repaired Lingguang Temple, which was after it was destroyed by weapons and armor.
After Gao and Qi, they both hid on Mount Tiantai to practice Chan meditation, and they died on the mountain one after another. When they were cremated, they all obtained relics.

The Biography of Shi Wenju of Guoqing Temple on Mount Tiantai in the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Shi Wenju of Guoqing Temple on Mount Tiantai in the Tang Dynasty, Shi Wenju, whose surname was Zhang, was from Dongyang, Wuzhou.
At the age of just beginning to study, he then left home to request the Dharma from a teacher.
At nineteen, he shaved his head and began to practice non-killing.
In the third year of the Zhenyuan era, he was ordained by imperial decree.
In the following fifteen years, he studied the Four Part Vinaya, diligently practicing day and night, and eventually ascended to the position of lecturer.
Next, he thoroughly understood the commentary on the Lotus Sutra and obtained the rich essence of the teachings of Zhiyi.
His body was over six feet tall, his appearance was like a mountain, his face was like jade, he was still like still water, and he moved like floating clouds.
His eyes never looked back, and his mouth never spoke playfully. In the four dignified deportments, he was a model of discipline.
The two assemblies of Danqiu looked up to him as a standard.
Those who rushed to other places to listen and receive teachings, along with Foku Zhegong's Chan teachings, drove side by side and vied with each other in excellence.
He was then ordered to be the great virtuous one of Guoqing Temple.

Previously, when the Great Master Zhizhe answered the questions of Emperor Yang of the Sui dynasty, he established the Seven-Day Golden Light Altar, and every year in the ninth month, officials from distant and near prefectures and counties sent offerings. Since the matter was unobstructed, the black and white two groups came from far away, and the number of people was so great that food and drink were lacking.
The monks in charge of meals suffered from this.
In the Dali era, the monk Qing Yun consulted with Ju and established a temple estate of twelve qing.
From then on, the Golden Light Assembly did not hear of any shortage, and this was Ju's merit!
In the second year of the Huichang era, he passed away in the fifth month. His disciple You Qing erected a stupa for him on the western peak of the temple.
He was 83 years old at that time, and had been a monk for 55 years.
Han Xi wrote a stele inscription to praise his virtues.

Biography of Yun Wen of Kaiyuan Temple in Kuaiji, Tang Dynasty. Biography of Yun Wen of Kaiyuan Temple in Kuaiji, Tang Dynasty. Shi Yun Wen, whose courtesy name was Zhi Jing, had the surname Zhu, and was a person from Jiahe in present-day Xuzhou.
When Quan Yu was nine years old, his father passed away. He then left home to follow the Buddha's teachings.

His teacher taught him the Vimalakirti Sutra and the Lotus Sutra. With his quick and sharp nature, he mastered both sutras in two years. The highly accomplished masters called him a person of profound understanding.
Someone joked and asked Wen:
After you leave home, what kind of work do you plan to do?
He immediately replied:
I will ascend to the Lotus Flower Platform and roar the lion's roar.
Someone scolded him, saying:
How dare you act like this in front of the elders?
Someone else said:
His ambition is great. It will not be easy to measure this child in the future.
At the age of sixteen, he shaved his head and put on the an-ta-hui robe.

One after another, he packed up and went west to Mount Song, where he met the great virtuous monk Yuan, the ordination master, and received the unconditioned Dharma. At that time, he was twenty-three years old.
That summer, he studied the Vinaya school of the Faxiang Department and the Madhyamaka-Å›Ästra in the capital city, patched his clothes, and begged for food in the cold and heat for four weeks.
Having knocked on the gate of meaning, he must enter the teacher's room. The profound pivot and model of the Vinaya are especially seen to be subtle.
In the fifth year of the Dali era, he suddenly sighed, Is this the end?
Having returned to his hometown, he was ill for a long time and had no opportunity to lecture.
Later, he heard that the Great Nirvana Sutra was being lectured at Tianzhu Temple in Qiantang, which was a great gathering, and Wen went to study there.
After several years, his sharp points were already revealed.

In the first year of the Kai-cheng era, he traveled to the Tai-jiao mountains and rested at Jiaxiang Temple in Yue. The assembly relied on the pure fragrance and selected him to lecture on the sutras and Vinaya.
Wen restrained and listened to the disciples, being quite strict and stern. He always instructed them, saying:

The practice of bhiká¹£us is not the way of the household. They are fully endowed with the discipline of individual liberation and the common lot of the saá¹ƒgha. This is their intrinsic nature. Because of their diligence in form and color, their fear, and their defense,
in this way, they will quickly attain the fruit of the path.
If not, then the disciples will fall, and the teacher's path will be in vain.
Hearing his admonition, some wept and wailed, reformed their minds and changed their conduct, and their thoughts improved by half.
In the third year of the Huichang era, he moved to Jinglin Temple and focused on propagating the Nirvana Sutra.
During the time of Emperor Wuzong's purification, he was included in the search.
During the day, he wore the robes of a monk, and at night he put on the robes of a layperson. He did not violate the practice of a monk, but only avoided worldly criticism.
At the beginning of the Dazhong era, the empty gate was revived again, and the Dharma rituals were reorganized. He was then registered as one of the thirty people in Kaigen Temple.
In the seventh year, the elders of the temple ordered him to lecture on the Vinaya scriptures.
In the autumn of the third year of Qianfu (876), he stopped lecturing and read the Buddhist canon.
On the twenty-ninth day of the sixth month of the second year of Zhonghe (882), he passed away peacefully at the age of seventy-eight, with fifty-five years as a monk.
On the twelfth day of the seventh month of that year, he was buried on the sunny side of Shiqi Mountain.
His last words forbade the erection of a tomb.
When Wen lectured and ascended the seat, his disciples feared and respected him. When he spoke in a low voice, everyone was subdued. His admonitions and awe-inspiring virtue were like this.
In the three temples of Jiaxiang, Jinglin, and Dashi, he lectured on the Huayan Sutra twenty-seven times and on the MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra twenty-five times.
As for his character:
He had an ancient appearance, tall and thin, a pointed head, and dark hair. He held himself with dignity and composure, even more pure than a crane in the courtyard.
However, he also studied Confucianism and Mohism, admired Bai Juyi and Fu Xi, wrote his own biography, and composed a Tomb Inscription in advance, which he kept in his chest.
His disciple Huaizhi, while searching through the texts, saw this and wept with grief. He then followed his late master's wish and built a small stupa.
